docs.lead_paragraph: MANY people are struck by the seeming perversity of hair, particularly its tendency to depart from the head, where it's most wanted, and to crop up in places that - for women at least - are decided cosmetic liabilities. For some, in fact, excessive hairiness is more than just a cosmetic problem; it is a serious psychological handicap that can result in extreme self-consciousness and social isolation. The problem is perennial for women with unwanted hair on their faces and those who live year-round in balmy climes. And now, as summer approaches and Northerners begin to peel off the cloaks of winter, the presence of unwanted hair on other parts of the body is an increasing source of embarrassment and discomfort. The recent advent of higher-cut bathing suits has only intensified the problem by giving women one more area to worry about: the so-called bikini line between the inner thigh and groin.
